text: Gerald M. Friedman (1921–2011) was a distinguished professor in Geology and was one of the founders of modern rock sedimentation. Friedman was a professor in Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute (RPI) and the City University of New York (CUNY).http://www1.cuny.edu/mu/we-remember/2011/12/20/gerald-friedman- distinguished-professor-of-geology-dies-at-90/ ==Life== Friedman was born in Berlin, Germany, on July 27, 1921. Being a Jew, Friedman escaped the Nazis in 1938 to England. Friedman completed a bachelor's degree in the University of London in the year 1945, with Chemistry as the major and Geology as a minor. In the year 1945 Friedman immigrated to the United States and worked three years as a Chemist in Squibb.:de:Gerald M. Friedman ==Scientific contributions== Friedman published 573 papers and 19 books, http://archives.datapages.com/data/bull_memorials/096/096011/novmem.htm including the highly cited book "Principles of Sedimentology".https://www.amazon.com/Principles-Sedimentology-Gerald-M- Friedman/dp/0471752452 Friedman received numerous awards including the prestige William H. Twenhofel Medal (in 1997), the Sidney Powers Memorial Award (in 2000), and the Mary C. Rabbitt History And Philosophy of Geology Award (in 2005). Friedman was the founder and director of the Northeastern Science Foundation which hosts symposia and publishes several journals, including Northeastern Geology, Environmental Science, and Carbonates and Evaporites,http://www.rpi.edu/dept/ees/people/faculty/friedman.html as well as the Carbonates and Evaporites journal.Carbonates and Evaporites The Sue Tyler Friedman Medal was named after Friedman's wife, Sue (Tyler) Friedman.Sue Tyler Friedman Medal ==References== Category:1921 births Category:2011 deaths Category:American geologists Category:German emigrants to the United States Category:Alumni of the University of London Category:Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute faculty Category:City University of New York faculty
